snomtools.evaluation.driftcorrection module¶

class snomtools.evaluation.driftcorrection.Drift(data=None, template=None, stackAxisID=None, yAxisID=None, xAxisID=None, subpixel=True, method='cv.TM_CCOEFF_NORMED')[source]¶
__init__(data=None, template=None, stackAxisID=None, yAxisID=None, xAxisID=None, subpixel=True, method='cv.TM_CCOEFF_NORMED')[source]¶

Calculates the correlation of a given 2D template with all slices in a n-D dataset which gets projected onto the three axes stackAxis, yAxis, xAxis. Differend methods and subpixel accuracy are available. :param data: n-D dataset :param template: 2D template array :param stackAxisID: Axis, along which the template_matching is calculated :param yAxisID: ID of the first axis of the image, i.e. y :param xAxisID: ID of the second axis of the image, i.e. x :param subpixel: Generate subpixel accurate drift vectors :param method: Method to calculate the Correlation between template and data. Possible methods: ‘cv.TM_CCOEFF’, ‘cv.TM_CCOEFF_NORMED’ (default), ‘cv.TM_CCORR’, ‘cv.TM_CCORR_NORMED’, ‘cv.TM_SQDIFF’, ‘cv.TM_SQDIFF_NORMED’

__module__ = 'snomtools.evaluation.driftcorrection'¶
static extract_3Ddata(data, stackAxisID, yAxisID, xAxisID)[source]¶

Projects the data of a n-D dataset onto the 3D system of stackAxis, yAxis, xAxis. :param data: :param stackAxisID: Defines the stack axis that is not projected and can be use for template_matching :param yAxisID: ID of the first axis of the image, i.e. y :param xAxisID: ID of the second axis of the image, i.e. x :return: Dataset projected on the defined axes while keeping the stackAxis

static extract_templatedata(data, yAxisID, xAxisID)[source]¶

Transforms the data of a template for further processing in the template_matching method. :param data: Raw dataset as quantity with axisID’s :param yAxisID: ID of the first axis, i.e. y :param xAxisID: ID of the second axis, i.e. x :return: Data of the whole template projected onto the two defined axes.

static guess_templatedata(data, yAxisID, xAxisID)[source]¶

Generates a default template for the template_matching method. The template is generated in the center between 2/5 and 3/5 of the image. :param data: Any dataset as quantity with axisID’s :param yAxisID: ID of the first axis, i.e. y :param xAxisID: ID of the second axis, i.e. x :return: Projected ROI of the 2/5 to 3/5 field.

static subpixel_peak(max_var, results)[source]¶

Extrapolates the position of a maximum in a 2D array by logarithmical evaluation of it’s surrounding values. I.e. for x: max_new=max + ( log(f(x-1)) - log(f(x+1)) ) / ( 2*log(f(x-1)) + 2*log(f(x+1)) - 4*log(f(x)) )

Parameters:
  • max_var – tuple with position of the maximum
  • results – array with the values in which the subpixel maximum is to be found. Has to contain at least the neighbouring elements of max_var.
Returns:

tuple of subpixel accurate maximum position
static template_matching(data_to_match, template, method='cv.TM_CCOEFF_NORMED', subpixel=True)[source]¶

Uses the openCV matchTemplate function to calculate a correlation between a 2D template array and the 2D data array The coordinates of the maximum (or minimum for SQDIFF methods) of the calculated correlation are returned. :param data_to_match: 2D dataset :param template: 2D template which is used to calculate the correlation :param method: Method to calculate the Correlation between template and data. Possible methods: ‘cv.TM_CCOEFF’, ‘cv.TM_CCOEFF_NORMED’ (default), ‘cv.TM_CCORR’, ‘cv.TM_CCORR_NORMED’, ‘cv.TM_SQDIFF’, ‘cv.TM_SQDIFF_NORMED’ :param subpixel: Generate subpixel accurate drift vectors :return: Returns the coordinate (y,x) of the correlation maximum referenced to the top left corner of the template.

classmethod template_matching_stack(data, template, stackAxisID, method='cv.TM_CCOEFF_NORMED', subpixel=True)[source]¶

Passes the data of a 3D array along the stackAxis in form of 2D data to the template_matching function :param data: 3D dataset :param template: 2D template which is used to calculate the correlation :param stackAxisID: Axis along which the 2D data is extracted and passed for template_matching :param method: Method to calculate the Correlation between template and data. Possible methods: ‘cv.TM_CCOEFF’, ‘cv.TM_CCOEFF_NORMED’ (default), ‘cv.TM_CCORR’, ‘cv.TM_CCORR_NORMED’, ‘cv.TM_SQDIFF’, ‘cv.TM_SQDIFF_NORMED’ :param subpixel: Generate subpixel accurate drift vectors :return: List of tuples containing the coordinates of best correlation

snomtools.evaluation.microscopy.normalize_by_flatfield_sum(data, flatfield_data, data_id=0, flat_id=0, newlabel='norm_int', new_plotlabel='Normalized Intensity')[source]¶

Normalizes a dataset by the data of another set, that was obtained on an unstructured surface and should therefore be “flat” (flatfield). The data is normalized by the sum over all other channels in the dataset, so only the spacial image is normalized, while all other axes are kept at constant relative values. The normalized data is written into a new DataArray in the given DataSet.

Parameters:
  • data – The DataSet instance of the data to normalize or a string with the filepath of the hdf5 file containing the data.
  • flatfield_data – The DataSet instance of the flatfield correction to apply or a string with the filepath of the hdf5 file containing the data.
  • data_id – A valid identifier of the DataArray in the DataSet instance to apply normalization to. Per default, the first DataArray is taken.
  • flat_id – A valid identifier of the DataArray in the flatfield DataSet instance to take as reference. Per default, the first DataArray is taken.
  • newlabel – The label to set for the created DataArray.
  • new_plotlabel – The plotlabel to set for the created DataArray.
Returns:

The modified dataset.

snomtools.evaluation.peem_dld module¶

snomtools.evaluation.peem_dld.energy_apply_calibration(data, kalfitfilename, mode='quadratic')[source]¶

Applies an energy calibration from a kalfit.txt file to a DLD DataSet. The channel axis will be replaced with an energy axis.

Parameters:
  • data – The DataSet instance of the data to normalize or a string with the filepath of the Tiff file from PEEM.
  • kalfitfilename – The filename of the text file from Terra that contains Energy Calibration fit parameters. Usually this file’s name ends with “kalfit.txt”.
  • mode – The mode for the energy calculation. Options: ‘quadradic’ (default) and ‘linear’
Returns:

The modified dataset.

snomtools.evaluation.peem_dld.normalize_by_flatfield_sum(data, flatfield_data, data_id=0, flat_id=0, newlabel='norm_int', new_plotlabel='Normalized Intensity')[source]¶

Normalizes a dataset by the data of another set, that was obtained on an unstructured surface and should therefore be “flat” (flatfield). The data is normalized by the sum over all energy channels, so only the spacial image is normalized, while all time channels are kept at constant relative values. The normalized data is written into a new DataArray in the given DataSet. This function essentialy shadows the function of the same name in snomtools.evaluation.microscopy, but adds a standard import for PEEM DLD tiff files.

Parameters:
  • data – The DataSet instance of the data to normalize or a string with the filepath of the Tiff file from PEEM.
  • flatfield_data – The DataSet instance of the flatfield correction to apply or a string with the filepath of the Tiff file from PEEM.
  • data_id – A valid identifier of the DataArray in the DataSet instance to apply normalization to. Per default, the first DataArray is taken.
  • flat_id – A valid identifier of the DataArray in the flatfield DataSet instance to take as reference. Per default, the first DataArray is taken.
  • newlabel – The label to set for the created DataArray.
  • new_plotlabel – The plotlabel to set for the created DataArray.
Returns:

The modified dataset.

static fit_fermi_edge(energies, intensities, guess=None)[source]¶

This function fits a fermi edge to data. Uses numpy.optimize.curve_fit under the hood.

Parameters:
  • energies – A quantity or array of energies. If no quantity, electronvolts are assumed.
  • intensities – Quantity or array: The corresponding intensity values to powers.
  • guess – optional: A tuple of start parameters (E_f, dE, c, d) as defined in fermi_edge method.
Returns:

The coefficients and uncertainties of the fitted fermi edge E_f, dE, c, d, as defined in fermi_edge method.

snomtools.evaluation.pes.fermi_edge(E, E_f, dE, c, d)[source]¶

The typical shape of a fermi edge for constant DOS. Suitable as a fit function, therefore it takes only floats, no quantities.

Parameters:
  • E – The x-Axis of the data consists of energies in eV
  • E_f – The Fermi energy in eV.
  • dE – Energy Resolution. The broadening of the Fermi edge on top of the thermal broadening, which is introduced by all experimental errors, in eV.
  • c – The height of the Fermi edge, in whichever units the data is given, e.g. “counts”.
  • d – Offset of the lower level of the fermi edge, e.g. “dark counts”.
Returns:

The value of the Fermi distribution at the energy E.
